teamMembers.name: Zaina Otieno
teamMembers.member_paragraph: Zaina has a background in the energy and investment space with top tier investment banking on wall street and canary wharf. She then moved back to Kenya, where she was born and raised, to work with Crossboundary as part of their investment team to deploy capital for energy projects across the African continent. On the podcast we explore:
member_bullets: Her journey into the energy investment space
The driving force behind her move back to Kenya
Adapting to the different working cultures between wall street/canary wharf and Nairobi
Working in large investment banks vs. boutique investment firms
Attracting more women into the energy and investment space
Capital raising challenges for energy projects in Africa
The most important lessons she has learnt throughout her career
teamMembers.member_quote: " There have been challenging moments. Honestly, there were moments when I was ready to step out. Ready to quit and take a different career trajectory. There is always a voice in your head reminding you that you don’t fit but it’s important to shut that voice and remind yourself of what you bring to the table. "
teamMembers.quote_attribute: - Zaina on challenging moments she has faced being a female in the energy and investment sector

teamMembers.name: Andreas Sakellaris
teamMembers.member_paragraph: Andreas has a background negotiating and structuring corporate PPAs across the world with some of the world's biggest energy consumers. He previously worked at Bain & Company within their private equity practice before moving into the energy space. He has worked across Africa, Asia, Central, North and South America, Europe and speaks 8 languages! On the podcast we explore:
member_bullets: Moving from management consulting into the energy sector
Whether corporates are serious about their decarbonisation targets
The potential role of carbon capture in decarbonising certain industries
The challenges (and joys) of developing projects in emerging markets
Getting energy buyers comfortable with signing long-term corporate PPAs.
teamMembers.member_quote: “There is an opportunity here to help developing countries industralise through renewables and I find it really exciting when I’m able to structure a deal that is able to help to do that to some extent. ”
teamMembers.quote_attribute: — Andreas on what he enjoys most about the work that he does

teamMembers.name: Erik Rakhou
teamMembers.member_paragraph: Erik began his journey within the Hydrogen sector in 2017, out of personal interest and a desire to shape an industry that was at a nascent stage. Fast forward to 2023 - he has worked on over 50 clients cases within the sector with Baringa Partners & Boston Consulting Group, co-authored a book on our hydrogen future called “Touching Hydrogen Future” and chaired the World Hydrogen Leaders congress. On the podcast we explore:
member_bullets: The motivation behind the “Touching Hydrogen Future” book
The book writing and publishing journey
Why the book took a colourless approach to hydrogen
The challenges (and joys) of developing projects in emerging markets
Solving the issue of water accessibility for GH2 projects
Key takeaways on Africa’s Hydrogen potential
The importance of governmental support
teamMembers.member_quote: “To inspire (the future hydrogen workforce) on how the future could look like in their country... You travel around the world, login to different countries and picture how it feels to be standing there in 2030/2040. It is also to give free means of reading about it before following the path.”
teamMembers.quote_attribute: — Erik on the inspiration behind the "Touching Hydrogen Future" book

teamMembers.name: Dan Demilew
teamMembers.member_paragraph: Dan has a background in delivering critical infrastructure projects across Europe, Middle-East, Africa and Australia. He found his way into the Green Hydrogen sector with Fortescue Future Industries, attracted by the prospect of helping a start-up scale in a new and exciting technology. Through that journey he has gone on to establish himself as an industry specialist and is the author of the Green Hydrogen Insight newsletter.  On the podcast we explore:
member_bullets: His journey into the Green Hydrogen sector
The various colours of Hydrogen
Hydrogen use cases and the impact on reducing CO2 emissions
Busting the Hydrogen myths
Solving the issue of water accessibility for GH2 projects
Africa’s Green Hydrogen potential
teamMembers.member_quote: “Africa has this tremendous intersection of opportunities (renewable energy potential, affordable land compared to Europe and a very capable workforce) that is not too dissimilar to what the Middle-East had in the 50s and 60s. This is Africa’s opportunity. ”
teamMembers.quote_attribute: — Dan on Africas Green Hydrogen Potential

teamMembers.name: Bhavik Pattni
teamMembers.member_paragraph: Bhavik is at the forefront of the data centre boom in Africa. He started his career working in private equity before moving to Raxio where he has played a key role in helping them become one of Africa’s premier data centre companies. On the podcast we explore:
member_bullets: The driving force behind Raxio’s growth
How DC companies can approach scaling their teams
Raising capital within the sector
Busting the Hydrogen myths
The challenges that might hinder the growth of the sector
Raxio’s ambitions moving forward
teamMembers.member_quote: “I’m very bullish about using renewable energy to power data centres. We are experimenting with newer technologies that the continent has not yet seen.”
teamMembers.quote_attribute: — Bhavik on the feasibility of using renewable energy to power data centres

teamMembers.name: Diana Mongare
teamMembers.member_paragraph: Diana is a rising star when it comes to investment facilitation for SMEs in East Africa. She currently works at Future Africa, where she helps their portfolio companies get investment ready and is also a founding member of the Nairobi Business Angel Network. On this podcast, we explore:
member_bullets: The Nairobi Business Angel Network (NaiBan)
The need for a stronger local funding ecosystem
Capital raising tips for start-ups
Funding disparity between male and female founders
Keeping African talent in Africa
teamMembers.member_quote: “The summary of what could be done is as short as less mentorship (for women) and more investments. If we just move away telling them how to do it or how to raise and just give them funding.”
teamMembers.quote_attribute: — Diana on bridging the funding disparity between male and female founders.
